original_data.question: A 16-year-old female presents to her physician’s office after noticing a round lump in her left breast 2 months ago. She reports that the lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses. It is otherwise painless, and the patient denies any discharge or skin changes. She has no past medical history but her grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The patient is an avid softball player at her high school and denies alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use. On exam, the breasts appear symmetric and normal. A 3-cm round, mobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy on either side. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?

options.A: This mass will decrease in size if the patient starts oral contraceptives
options.B: This mass slightly increases this patient’s risk of breast cancer in the future
options.C: This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time
options.D: If this mass grows rapidly to greater than 5 cm, radiation and chemotherapy are indicated

model_response:
The most likely outcome of this patient’s condition is that the mass will decrease in size or disappear over time. The patient’s age and the description of the mass make fibroadenoma the most likely diagnosis. Fibroadenomas are benign tumors that are frequently seen in adolescents and young adults. They are firm, mobile masses that are well-circumscribed and usually do not cause pain. Fibroadenomas do not increase the risk of breast cancer, but the family history of breast cancer in this patient is concerning. The patient should be reassured that the mass is benign and that the risk of breast cancer is not increased. The patient should be counseled to perform monthly breast self-exams and to return for follow-up if there is any change in the size or characteristics of the mass.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The room or rooms in which the physician and staff provide patient care. The offices include all rooms in the physician's office suite.
The shape of a circle.
The hemispheric projection, including the mammary gland, located on the anterior portion of the chest, lateral to the midline, on the side of the body to the west when facing north.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
The act of increasing (something) in size or volume or quantity or scope.
Applied to pain that is tender, i.e., elicited by touching the affected body part. []

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Not causing physical or psychological misery, pain or distress.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The pouring forth of a fluid.
A question about whether an individual has or had noticed changes in their skin.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
The mother of your father or mother.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
An invasive (infiltrating) CARCINOMA of the mammary ductal system (MAMMARY GLANDS) in the human BREAST.
In humans, one of the paired regions in the anterior portion of the THORAX. The breasts consist of the MAMMARY GLANDS, the SKIN, the MUSCLES, the ADIPOSE TISSUE, and the CONNECTIVE TISSUES.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A secondary school that usually includes grades 9 through 12.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
Willful or deliberate act of inhaling and exhaling SMOKE from burning substances or agents held by hand.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
In humans, one of the paired regions in the anterior portion of the THORAX. The breasts consist of the MAMMARY GLANDS, the SKIN, the MUSCLES, the ADIPOSE TISSUE, and the CONNECTIVE TISSUES.
In pathology, a term that is used to describe a tissue specimen that has a normal appearance.
The shape of a circle.
Moving or capable of moving readily.
In a place or position that is higher.
One quarter of a circle. In anatomy, one part of an area divided into quarters for descriptive purposes.
The hemispheric projection, including the mammary gland, located on the anterior portion of the chest, lateral to the midline, on the side of the body to the west when facing north.
A dull achy pain.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
A clinical finding indicating the enlargement of the lymph nodes in the axillary region. It may be caused by infections, systemic diseases, or cancer.
A line segment forming part of the perimeter of a plane figure.
The result of an action.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
